description:
Bhargavaea ullalensis is a species of bacteria that was first isolated from soil samples collected in Ullal, India. It belongs to the phylum Proteobacteria, specifically the class Gammaproteobacteria.

The cells of Bhargavaea ullalensis are Gram-negative, rod-shaped, and motile with the help of flagella. They are capable of aerobic respiration and can grow at temperatures ranging from 20°C to 45°C, with an optimal growth temperature of around 37°C.

Phylogenetic analysis based on 16S rRNA gene sequences has shown that Bhargavaea ullalensis is closely related to other members of the genus Bhargavaea, which are known to be soil-dwelling bacteria.

The species was named in honor of the Indian microbiologist Dr. C.V. Bhargava, who has made significant contributions to the field of microbiology in India.
